dialogues.speaker: STREET ARTIST
dialogues.text: Very nearly there, sir. I have to say, your face is familiar. Have I drawn you before?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Occasionally.

dialogues.speaker: STREET ARTIST
dialogues.text: Of course, I've seen you in the newspaper. You’re a reporter? ANGLE ON: A WHITE DOG is sitting, looking a little bored, the subject’s feet. The DOG whimpers.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I'm a journalist. Be patient, Snowy - not much longer. Two patent leather shoes enter frame, distracting SNOWY. SNOWY leaves to follow the MAN, who deftly picks the pock of market patrons as he goes. ANGLE ON: SNOWY as he trots through the crowd, keeping hi eyes on the PICKPOCKET. The PICKPOCKET bumps into another market patron and snatc their wallet.

dialogues.speaker: PICKPOCKET
dialogues.text: I do beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: SNOWY follows the PICKPOCKET as a hand continue snatch wallets and handbags from their unsuspecting owner

dialogues.speaker: STREET ARTIST
dialogues.text: There. I believe I’ve captured something of your likeness. The STREET ARTIST hands TINTIN the picture, showing the CARTOON TINTIN. Our fully-dimensional TINTIN admires it.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Not bad. What do you think, Snowy? TINTIN looks around - SNOWY isn’t there. TINTIN (CONT’D) (exasperated) Snowy... TINTIN hands money to the artist and leaves, in search of SNOWY.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are, sir. Now, where's he run off to? As TINTIN stroils through the market, he passes two pairs eyes (the THOM(P)SONS), peering through holes cut in a NEWSPAPER.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Nothing! TINTIN crosses behind them.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Snowy! TINTIN has paused by a stall selling mirrors, which refle multiple images of his famous quiff. A DOG BARK. SNOWY runs over.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where have you been, heh? Chasing cats again? ANGLE ON: TINTIN, just as something has caught his eye in reflection of a stall selling cheap antiques.  TINTIN (CONT’D) Snowy - look at this! CLOSE ON: A magnificent model sailing ship in a glass cas TINTIN and SNOWY walk towards it and bend down to take a closer look. TINTIN leans in closer. Intricate detail fills the frame, if the boat were real. We can almost hear the sea, the sh of sailors, the cry of gulls. TINTIN (CONT‘D) Triple masted, double decks, fifty guns. Isn’t she a beauty?

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That's a very unique specimen, that is. The seller, CRABTREE, is sitting at his stall. CRABTREE (CONT’D) From an old sea captain’s estate,

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: The Unicorn...

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: Unicorn. “Man-o-War” sailing ship. It's very old, that is. Sixteenth century!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Seventeenth, I would think.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: Reign of Charles the First!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Charles the Second.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: That's what I said, Charles the Second. As fine a ship as ever sailed the seven seas. You won’t find another one of these, mate. And it’s only two quid.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I‘ll give you a pound.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: (relieved) Done!  CRABTREE stands as TINTIN pays him. ANGLE ON: BARNABY, a large man in a tight blue suit, is lumbering through the market, distracted and under pressu CRABTREE lifts the model ship from the case and hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gently does it. BARNABY continues to shove his way through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: MARKET PATRON
dialogues.text: Excuse me! CRABTREE releases the boat into TINTIN’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: There you go, careful! SUDDENLY: An AMERICAN VOICE!

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, bud... BARNABY arrives at the stall, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...how much for the boat?

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just sold it to this young gent.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Tell me what you paid and I'll give you double.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: (appalled) Double?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Thanks, but it's not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Look, kid, I’m trying to help you out - I don't think you realize this, but you're about to walk into a whole mess of danger.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What kind of danger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARNABY’s expression changes to a look of alarm.

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: I’m warning you - get rid of the boat and get out while you still can! These people do not play nice. BARNABY moves back into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What people?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Wonderful! TINTIN turns around to find a TALL, STOOPED-MAN standing behind him - this is SAKHARINE. He wears a long macintosh tall bowler, with a coal black beard, fierce bright eyes pince-nez.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: It's just, wonderful! Don't bother wrapping it, I'll take it - ‘as is’. Does anybody object if I pay by cheque?

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: If you want to buy it, you'll have to talk to the kid!

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: I see. Well, let the kid name his price.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: (quiet despair) Name his price?? Ten yeare I've been flogging bric-a-brac and I miss “name your price” by one bleedin’ minute!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I already explained to the other gentleman - SAKHARINE frowns, locking around.

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: American - he was. All hair oil and no socks!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: It’s not for sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let me appeal to your better nature. I have recently acquired Marlinspike Hall and this ship, as I’m sure you’re aware, was once part of the estate.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Of the late sea captain?

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: The family fell upon hard times, lost everything. They’d been living in a cloud of bad luck ever since. We are talking generations of drinking and irrational behavior -

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry but as I told you before, it‘s not for sale. SAKHARINE glares at TINTIN. TINTIN (CONT’D) Good day to you, sir. TINTIN tucks the MODEL SHIP under his arm, nods politely, leaves. SNOWY cocks his snout indignantly and follows.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: That young man - what‘s his name?

dialogues.speaker: CRABTREE
dialogues.text: Him? Everybody knows him. That's Tintin. CLOSE ON: SAKHARINE as the camera closes in on his inscrutable face. INT. TINTIN’S APARTMENT - DAY TINTIN and SNOWY enter.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What is it about this ship? Why has it attracted so much attention? He sets the model down on his sideboard. TINTIN studies the MODEL SHIP ...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What secrets do you hold?  7. TINTIN hurries to the next room. He takes off his coat an sets it down on the couch. He enters a small office and h around his desk for his magnifying glass; an old typewrit sits there in pride of place, surrounded by artifacts fro far-off places. TINTIN (CONT’D) Ah! Where ia that magnifying glaas? As TINTIN looks around - we see glimpses of his LIFE: fra PICTURES and NEWSPAPER STORIES, featuring past adventures TINTIN posing with familiar CHARACTERS from early travels TINTIN (CONT’D) Could have sworn it was... No. Where could it possibly be? Snowy, you haven't seen... He moves to the large bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is it? SNOWY surprises him, he is holding the magnifying glaas i his jaws. TINTIN (CONT‘D) Thank you. TINTIN takes it. CLOSE ON: MAGNIFYING GLASS. He turns around to find the c standing in the doorway. SNOWY turns and GROWLS! TINTIN (CONT’D) No, Snowy! ANGLE ON: A WHITE CAT has slipped in through the open win SNOWY instantly BARKS and chases the CAT, which springs b up into the living room. TINTIN rushes back into the living room, and finda SNOWY chasing the CAT. The CAT swings wildly from a chandelier, climbs up the dr and over a bookshelf; SNOWY goes above it. As he races ac the sideboard after the CAT, he knocks over the UNICORN! TINTIN chases the CAT towards the window and slides on th floor. He hears the CRASH! TINTIN spins around the SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The MODEL SHIP lies on the floor... mast broke near the base, TINTIN gently picks up the BROKEN MODEL SHIP.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Look what you did. You broke it! Bad dog! He turns the ship over, not noticing a SMALL METAL TUBE t drops onto the FLOOR. CLOSE ON: TINTIN moves closer to the sideboard and unknowingly kicks the tube under the low cabinet. SNOWY t to PAW at it, but it rolls away... the more SNOWY paws at the further he pushes it... until it rolls all the way un the cabinet. CLOSE ON: TINTIN examines the damage ... the mast is holl and has snapped near the deck, TINTIN pute the MAST loose back in place.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something happened on this ship. And we're going to the one place that could have the answer ... TINTIN grabs hia coat and heads out of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: c'mon, Snowy. TINTIN and SNOWY leave the apartment. Someone is watching through binoculars from outside the window. They focus on SHIP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: TINTIN site in the gothic library, a tiny figur dwarfed by towering shelves. CLOSE ON: TINTIN is reading a old thick maritime encyclopedia. He turns the page and whispers to SNOWY.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (low whiaper) Here it is! "Sir Francis Haddock of Marlinspike Hall the last Captain of the ill-fated Unicorn ... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The ship set sail from Barbados in 1676 on one of the most ruinous voyages in maritime history... ship never reached destination... An old illustration of the UNICORN under full sail. TINTIN (CONT’D) «-.attacked by pirates, all hands lost except for one survivor. When Sir Francis was rescued and returned home, he was convinced his name had been cursed. The Unicorn's manifest stated that it was carrying a cargo of rum and tobacco bound for Europe, but it was long claimed the ship was carrying a secret cargo... TINTIN glances at SNOWY, puzzled...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was the ship carrying, Snowy? TINTIN turns another page and keeps reading ...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Historians have tried and failed to discover what happened on that fatal voyage - but Sir Francis’s last words: ‘Only a true Haddock will discover the secret of the Unicorn.’ TINTIN turns the page to continue, then puts the book dow and grabs another, flipping through the pages. A familiar blue-suited figure sneaks between the aiales.. TINTIN takes a look behind his shoulder - there is no one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN is a little creeped out. A storm is brewing, and rain beats on the library windows. TINTIN thinks he’s being watched. Lightning strikes outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN enters the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I've missed something, Snowy. We need to take a closer look at that model.  10. He walks up the stairs. INT. TINTIN’S FLAT - EVENING TINTIN opens the door and enters. The model ship has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Of course it’s gone! How could I be so stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faded sign indicating “MARLINSPIKE HALL” can still be r ANGLE ON: TINTIN and SNOWY hurry along in the shadows of high brick wall that surrounds a country estate. A full moon casts spooky shadows through skeletal trees, blowing in the wind. With every gust, a carpet of dead le lift into the air. ANGLE ON: The rusting iron gates, covered with ivy. TINTIN reaches the gate he tries to open them, to no avai Suddenly, SNOWY appears on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: How'd you do that? SNOWY shows TINTIN a hole in the crumbled wall. TINTIN (CONT’D) Clever boy. TINTIN squeezes through the hole, with SNOWY close behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: TINTIN and SNOWY cross the heavily wooded estat a dark mansion. ANGLE ON: MARLINSPIKE HALL ... a once-grand chateau-style COUNTRY HOUSE, now looking very sad and neglected. Empty dark. TINTIN walks up to the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ll. ANGLE ON: TINTIN’S flashlight sweeps and settles on a COA ARMS, carved into stone above the front door. A large fis dominates the design.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (whispers) A coat of arms... why does that look familiar? (realizes) Hang on a minute... that fish! It's a Haddock! Of course - Marlinspike Hall is the old Haddock estate... SNOWY quickly heads off on in the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Snowy! A slavering GUARD DOG growls and charges at TINTIN from o of the shadows! ANGLE ON: TINTIN races away from the DOG, leaping fallen trees and ducking low branches, with the hound snapping a his heels. TINTIN approaches a stone wall as the DOG is almost upon Suddenly, SNOWY leaps from the bramble and barks angrily the GUARD DOG. The larger dog cowers and whines, submitti to SNOWY’S ferocity. TINTIN (CONT‘D) Well done, Snowy! Good boy. TINTIN pets his head. The GUARD DOG playfully runs about SNOWY on the front law as TINTIN unlatches a broken window and climbs inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: TINTIN slowly pushes open the window inside the mansion and carefully sweeps his FLASHLIGHT through a darkened room. Everything is coated in layers of dust and furniture is covered in great white sheets. A shadowy fig stealthily walks alongside him. TINTIN moves through a door into a side room, where he se distinctive SHAPE hidden beneath a sheet. In one swift movement, he sweeps the sheet aside. ANGLE ON: The MODEL SHIP sitting in a display case, bathe a shaft of ghostly moonlight.  12. CLOSE ON: TINTIN can’t believe hia luck ... he grabs the MODEL SHIP. He shines the flashlight on the boat before picking it up.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (softly) Well, well, well... it seems we've caught our thief. He starts to back away from the case holding onto the shi He turns to see a tall, SILHOUETTED FIGURE standing in fr of him ... the MAN raises a CANDLESTICK and whacks TINTIN his HEAD!

dialogues.speaker: THUNK
dialogues.text: TINTIN slumps to the FLOOR, head spinning. The room light are turned on. NESTOR takea the UNICORN from TINTIN asa he is lying on t floor, making sure his head is still attached. SAKHARINE enters, completely cool and calm.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: Welcome to Marlinspike Hall. I see you let yourself in. TINTIN gets up.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I came to retrieve my property.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - I’m not sure I follow you? TINTIN sits up, rubbing the back on his head. NESTOR is holding the UNICORN MODEL.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, I think you do. This ship was atolen from my apartment leas than an hour ago! TINTIN tries to get the MODEL SHIP from NESTOR - as if he thinking of making a dash for it.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you're mistaken, Mr. Tintin. NESTOR pulls the ship back from TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: There’s no mistake. It belongs to me! He pulls back again away from NESTOR.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: Are you sure? NESTOR begins to pulls the ship away from TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: of course I’m sure. TINTIN takes the SHIP.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I took it home. I put it ona _ cabinet in the living room and then Snowy chased the cat and knocked it over and it ... (dawning realization) ++. fell. TINTIN’S eye is drawn to the mast. This mast is not broke and split like that on his own ship.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {stunned) This isn't my ship.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: No, indeed. NESTOR takes the SHIP back, and goes back to the case and puts it inside.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I - I’m sorry. It looks — identical. SAKHARINE takes TINTIN by the arm and leads him out towar the door.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: Well, looks can be deceiving.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed ... TINTIN pulls away from SAKHARINE and walks back to the ca and the ship.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +». but I don’t understand! Why did Sir Francis make two ships exactly alike? And you have one already. Why do you want another? What is it about this model that would cause someone to steal it?

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: Goodness me, why so many questions?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: It‘s my job. There could be a story here. It’s what I do, you see.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: Well, it's no great mystery. Sir Francis Haddock was a drunkard and a hopeless reprobate! He was doomed to fail and he bequeathed that failure to his sons. He starts to walks away from TINTIN, TINTIN follows him.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: So it’s true! The Haddock line is cursed! He stops TINTIN with his cane.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: What else have you found out? TINTIN pushes the cane away.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What is there to find? SAKHARINE swings the cane to TINTIN’s other shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: That depends what you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I'm looking for answers, Mr. Sakharine ...

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: You're looking in the wrong place. SAKHARINE offers TINTIN a THIN SMILE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAKHARINE (CONT’D) It's late ... I think you should go home. NESTOR handa the torch to TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: This way, Sir. NESTOR and TINTIN leave the room. SAKHARINE takes a look the ship.

dialogues.speaker: INT, MARLINSPIKE HALL FOYER
dialogues.text: NESTOR escorts a aullen TINTIN out.

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: It’s a pity, sir. TINTIN turns.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: That the mast broke on your model ship, sir. I hope you found all the pieces. Things are so easily loat.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Nestor! Where are you?!

dialogues.speaker: NESTOR
dialogues.text: Good night, sir. NESTOR closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: TINTIN and SNOWY walk down the dark, wet street TINTIN’S apartment.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Some thing's are easily lost. What did he mean by that, Snowy? What was he trying to tell me? Some things are easily lost ...  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN and SNOWY climb the stairs to their apartment. The door is ajar. TINTIN enters and turns on the lights. ANGLE ON: TINTIN'S flat has been RANSACKED!!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Great snakes! Furniture overturned... books thrown off shelves... drawe pulled and emptied. CLOSE ON: SNOWY whimpering and clawing at the CABINET.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is it, Snowy? TINTIN pulls the CABINET aside to reveal the METAL TUBE. He squats down and picks up the tiny metal tube from the broken mast, TINTIN stands and examines the TUBE. TINTIN (CONT‘D) What’s this? A ha! This was in the mast. TINTIN walks over to the table sits down. CLOSE ON: TINTIN unscrews the lid and shakes the TUBE... small parchment, wrapped in ribbon and sealed with wax, f into his palm. ANGLE ON: TINTIN at the table ... SNOWY brings the magnif glass in his jaws.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good boy, Snowy. TINTIN carefully unfurls the PARCHMENT and studies it. Written ornately across it in faded quill:

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reading) “Three brothers joined. Three Unicorns in company, sailing in the new day sun will speak. For tis from the Light that Light will dawn, and then shine forth the fagle's Cross." Beneath that, a few seemingly meaningless strokes and das  17. TINTIN (CONT‘D) What are these markings? Some kind of secret language, or code? It makes no sense. But it does explain why they ransacked the flat. They were looking for this, and they didn't find it, which means ... they'll be back. The doorbell downstairs JANGLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: TINTIN tucking the scroll carefully into his wa as he creeps down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FINCH
dialogues.text: No, I don't know where he is, Dearie. I think he's gone out. And anyway, it's after dark and Mr. Tintin is most particular about not admitting visitors after bedtime. I have to go back to my cocoa. I've got a very good book and a cup of cocoa. It's really lovely... TINTIN steps forward to see MRS. FINCH talking to an unse MAN at the door. The chain is still on, the door open onl crack.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mrs. Finch. I can look after this... MRS. FINCH shoots TINTIN a sour look, vanishes into her apartment. CLOSE ON: TINTIN approaching the door cautiously, a pisto his hand, which he keeps behind his back. A familiar American voice is heard:

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Hey kid, is that you? Open the door! BARNABY presses his face through the crack.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: Look, the game is up! He’s gonna be back! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, I know he wanted those boats, but I swear to God, I never thought he'd kill anyone over it.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Who? Who are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BARNABY
dialogues.text: I’m trying to tell you that your life is in danger - !

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Answer me! Who??? BANG! BANG! BANG! Bullet holes PUNCH through the door! TINTIN throws himself to the floor! The last bullet has taken out the chain. The door swings slowly open to reveal a bloody, unarmed BARNABY! He falls the floor.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {shouting) Mrs. Finch! A man's been shot on our doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FINCH
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Not again ...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Call an ambulance! TINTIN rushes into the street as a blue car drives away. SNOWY tries to chase after the CAR.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Snowy! SNOWY stops, but BARKS loudly. ANGLE ON: BARNABY lies on the doormat clawing desperately a newspaper. TINTIN runs back in. TINTIN rolls BARNABY over, but he’s out cold.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? Can you..- TINTIN picks up the newspaper, stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT, TINTIN’S APARTMENT - DAY ANGLE ON: TINTIN studying the blook-atained newspaper. TI lowers the paper, and before him stand the two plaincloth Interpol Detectives, THOMPSGN and THOMSON.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: The victim’s name was Barnaby Dawea.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: He was one of the top agents at Interpol but we haven't got a clue what he waa working on.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Quite right, Thompson. We're completely clueless.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Interpol doesn't have any other leads?

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Oh, steady on, Tintin - we're still filling out the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Police work's not all glamour and guns - there’s an awful lot of filing.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Well, I might have something for you. Before he lost consciousness, Dawes tried to tell me something and I think he was spelling out a word... BOUD... JAN, CLOSE ON: TINTIN traces each letter that BARNABY marked w a BLOODY FINGER PRINT.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Karaboudjan!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Does that mean anything to you? THOMSON snatches the newspaper from TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Great Scotland Yard! That’s extraordinary!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Worthington's have a half price sale on bowler hats! THOMPSON snatches the paper.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Well, is there somebody else in your family, maybe they would know?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Sir Francis had three sons. All but my bloodline failed. I am the last of the Haddocks.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Did you say ‘three’ sons?! A couple of CREW MEMBERS are approaching the stairs. HADD and TINTIN get down quickly and hide under the stairs wit SNOWY. The CREW MEMBERS move down the stairs and out the doorway SNOWY whimpers, and TINTIN tries to put his hand on SNOWY snout. One the crew are gone, HADDOCK heads wp the stairs, TINTI follows. CLOSE ON: TINTIN, realization dawning on his face.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know what Sakharine’s looking for!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: What are you raving on about?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: It was written on the scroll. {reciting) “Three brothers joined; three Unicorns in company sailing in the noonday sun will speak.”

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (excited) Sir Francis didn’t make two models of the Unicorn ~ he made three! Three ships for three sons! HADDOCK turns to TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Excellent. HADDOCK heads off, down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Sakharine's after the third model ship. HADDOCK try to wrench open a LOCKED DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Barnacles! Someone’s locked the door!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Well, is there a key?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: A key? Aah! HADDOCK breathes a sigh of ALCOHOL FUMES into TINTIN’s face,who coughs.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes ... now that would be the problem! HADDOCK returns the way they came, and TINTIN follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door quietly swings OPEN, revealing a gloomy dormitory of swaying bunks. Ugly, drunken CREWMEN sprawled in hammo SNORING. CLOSE ON: HADDOCK and TINTIN peering round the DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (whispers) Mr. Jaggerman, top bunk in the center - keeper of the keys. Careful mind, he's a restless sleeper on account of the tragic loss of his eyelids.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: He lost his eyelids?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Aye, now that was a card game to remember - ah, you really had to be there. I'd do this myself, Tintin, but you’ve a lighter tread and less chance of waking the boys.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: You've nothing to worry about. ANGLE ON: TINTIN sets off, sneaking between the bunks, towards the sleeping MR. JAGGERMAN - the KEYS are visible his hand. Haddock (CONT’D) (loud whisper) Provided they all stay asleep. TINTIN struggles to keep hia balance with the heavy yaw a roll of the ship. HADDOCK (CONT’D) Don’t, I wouldn’t get too close to Mr. Hobbs - he’s very handy with a razor. And I'd steer clear of Mr. Gitch - sacked as shepherd on account of his ‘animal husbandry’! TINTIN and SNOWY climb onto the high bunk, reaching for t KEYS hanging from JAGGERMAN’S HAND. ANGLE ON: TINTIN’S FINGERTIPS nearly touch the KEYS. He grabs SNOWY and holds him out towards the KEYS, but SN instead goes for JAGGERMAN’S SANDWICH.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Not the sandwich! The keys! TINTIN falls in a cascade of SNORING SAILORS, DEAD FISH a large SHARK CARCASS. SAILORS from surrounded bunks pile o top of him. CLOSE ON: SNOWY stands on top of the pile of SAILORS. TINTIN'S FIST, KEYS included, burat from the pile. HADDOC quietly claps.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: TINTIN hands the KEYS to an impressed HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: You're a brave lad, Tintin - my heart was in my mouth, I don’t mind telling you. HADDOCK unlocks the rusty door.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, that is, if it was my heart. You know, judging by my stomach, it could’ve been anything, really.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Hurry up, Captain. We’ve no time to lose - TINTIN freezes in DISBELIEF! The door opesn to reveal a storeroom filled with BOTTLES OF WHISKEY and RUM!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Bingo! Just the necessities, of course! HADDOCK quickly stuffs a few bottles into various pockets kisses one of the BOTTLES.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To the lifeboats. TINTIN stands AGHAST for a MOMENT, then follows HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DECK of the SHIP is covered with SAILORS searching wi FLASHLIGHTS. A group of WELDERS working on a SEAPLANE.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes peeled!

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: I’ll go aft!

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: Any sign of him, Buster?

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: Not yet! Watch yourself, the boss says he’s a handful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: HADDOCK stumbles out a door, onto the DECK and almost into TOM. TINTIN pulla him back inside at the last moment. TINTIN grabs HADDOCK bottle of WHISKEY, and goes back to clobber TOM. Just as TINTIN swings his ARM, HADDOCK snatc the BOTTLE ... TINTIN knocks TOM out with his FIST, glare and HADDOCK and shakes his sore hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a rough, stormy ocean. HADDOCK, TINTIN and SNOWY mov towards the lifeboat. HADDOCK and TINTIN quickly remove t ropes from the hooks and start to push the boat out towar the edge.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: Boas wants us to check the coms. Come out of it. SUDDENLY a door opens, we hear A MORSE CODE noise. ALLAN TOM pass by. ALLAN (CONT’D) Come on, in here. HADDOCK points in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: It's Allan! ALLAN and TOM walk through a door.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Is that the bridge?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Aye, on the other side of the radio room.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Radio room? TINTIN gestures for HADDOCK to stay put in the shadows. TINTIN (CONT’D) (hushed} Wait here, Captain. Sound the alarm if anyone comes.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Careful, Tintin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN has already moved towards the stairs ... SNOWY followa.

dialogues.speaker: SAILORS SEARCHING SHIP
dialogues.text: I aaid keep searching! There‘s no one here! Who we looking for, anyway? ANGLE ON: TINTIN sneaks to the RADIO ROOM door. ALLAN is TOM’S shoulder as he reads an incoming Morse message:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Message just come through, boas.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (reading) “The Milanese Nightingale has landed. Waiting in the wings for action.”

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Milanese Nightingale. TINTIN frowns... ALLAN calmly plucks the RADIO MESSAGE fr TOM'S HAND.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: (relieved) Now pray this cheers him up! As they disappear, TINTIN sneaks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN enters the room with SNOWY. SNOWY sees a SANDWICHE jumps on the desk and begins to eat, fighting a RAT for i ANGLE ON: TINTIN quickly searches for any clues to the sh destination. He scans charts, looks at written messages. picks up one of the notes and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Bagghar. TINTIN notices a BROCHURE with a picture of BAGGHAR and B SALAAD.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's this? He picks it up - and opens it at random. We see a picture the town. TINTIN (CONT‘D) (reading) The sultanate of Bagghar. A second page. A portrait of BEN SALAAD. TINTIN (CONT’‘D) (reading) Ruled over by Sheik Omar Ben Salaad, whose love of music and culture is matched only by his love of... TINTIN turns the page. He sees something that we don't.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Great snakes! He moves over to nearby wall covered in maps, quickly scanning for something...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bagghar. The port of Bagghar. Morocco! SUDDENLY, TINTIN gets an idea! TINTIN shoves the brochure into his pocket, quickly puts the headphones on and sits the desk, fiddling with the frequency knobs on the old ra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: HADDOCK holding onto the boat.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Tintin! ANGLE ON: A sleeping CREW MEMBER, huddled in the lifeboat wakes with a start and is surprised to find CAPTAIN HADDO holding one of the lifeboat ropes... he produces a PISTOL

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: Hey! Put your hands up! ANGLE ON: HADDOCK raises his HANDS, letting go of the ROP «+. the LIFEBOAT drops into the water, while the CREW MEM gets tangled in the ROPE and swings only a few feet from WATER.  46.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: And let that be a lesson to you! HADDOCK moves down to untie the next BOAT.

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: Help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: MORSE TAPPER ... click ... click ... click ... TINTIN is BUSY sending a MESSAGE. INT. KARABOUDJAN RADIO ROOM —- NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (shouting) In here! He’s in here! He raises his gun. SNOWY jumps up and grabs his arm, the FIRES, giving TINTIN a valuable second to REACT. TINTIN stands and punches TOM. We really see TINTIN'S abi to look after himself against a THUG, With the second pun TOM bumps into ALLAN as he is coming out. ALLAN gets tangled up with TOM. TINTIN grabs TOM's gun and runs out with SNOWY. ALLAN chases TINTIN, TOM follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN races from the RADIO ROOM as a GUARD spots HADDOCK

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Here! By the lifeboats!

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: Get out the way! TINTIN runs past with ALLAN right behind him. ALLAN (CONT’D) Get him!

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLAN and the GUARD open fire. TINTIN runs among cargo cr and punches another GUARD to the ground. The GUARD recove and fires a spray of bullets at TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Why, you little... ! ANGLE ON: TINTIN and SNOWY races along the deck and down stairs onto the deck BELOW, and SPRINT towards HADDOCK an the LIFEBOAT.

dialogues.speaker: SAILORS SEARCHING SHIP
dialogues.text: Oy! He's up there! Get him, lads! TINTIN has TOM’S PISTOL. HADDOCK falls into the LIFEBOAT where SNOWY is already waiting. The ROPE slips, and the B dangles precariously. HADDOCK slams into a SEAT, smashing number of BOTTLES hidden in his POCKETS; WHISKEY and BROK GLASS fall into the OCEAN below. TINTIN returns GUNFIRE, as ALLAN enters and fires at him. TINTIN fires at a SPOTLIGHT, hits the “ON” lever and turn the light on, blinding the CREW pursuing him. TINTIN jumps into the boat. CLOSE ON: TINTIN raisea the PISTOL, takes AIM ... BANG! TINTIN shoots the last ROPE, and the LIFEBOAT falls into the OCEAN with TINTIN, HADDOCK and SNOWY clinging on it! A SAILOR is tangled in the ROPE. r

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: Help me! An angry SAKHARINE strolls onto the DECK. ANGLE ON: TINTIN and HADDOCK row for their lives. ANGLE ON: ALLAN runs onto the BRIDGE.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: Turn the ship ‘round! Give me a flare!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: ALLAN runs back onto the DECK and fires a SIGNA FLARE into the SKY. ANGLE ON: TINTIN lies down in the BOAT.  48.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain! Get down! Get down! A CREW MEMBER spots a ROWBOAT using the SEARCHLIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: There he is!

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: Get out of the way! TOM runs to the BRIDGE.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Now full ahead! Full speed! The KARABOUDJAN speeds towards the BOAT.

dialogues.speaker: ALLAN
dialogues.text: Got you now! ANGLE ON: TINTIN and HADDOCK continue to hide.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Stay down! The ROWBOAT is demolished by the MASSIVE SHIP.

dialogues.speaker: CREW MEMBER
dialogues.text: Look! Down ‘ere! ANGLE ON: EMPTY BOTTLES float around rowboat debris at it sinka into the OCEAN. ANGLE ON: The second ROWBOAT, TINTIN and HADDOCK'S ROWBOA TINTIN sits up; they row away from the KARABOUDJAN. ANGLE ON: SAKHARINE approaches TOM. He is absolutely furi

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: Idiots! You idiots! What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: We killed them, boss. Like you wanted! SAKHARINE grabs TOM. About to throw him overboard.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: No. Not ‘like’ I wanted. I needed Haddock alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, boss. There are two boats missing.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: So that one must have been a decoy! 49. SAKHARINE'S EYES suddenly go to the ground beneath hia fe He bends over and he picks up the small piece of paper wi the Morse code and the word “Bagghar” written on it. SAKHARINE holds up the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: SAKHARINE
dialogues.text: They’re on to us, and our destination. Find them! Make absolutely certain they never reach Bagghar!

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, boss. SAKHARINE turns his head and we pan with his turn onto th SEA PLANE already rigged on a CATAPULT LAUNCHER at the st of the KARABOUDJAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up TINTIN, SNOWY and HADDOCK after their escape f the KARABOUDJAN. TINTIN rowing. They are all alone on the wide, wide open sea.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: We have to get to Bagghar ahead of Sakharine.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I know! I know! (beat) Why?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Because he has the third model ship.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: How do you know? TINTIN takes out the BROCHURE that he found in the RADIO ROOM.  50.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: The sheikh collects old ships and this is the prize of his collection. TINTIN opens the brochure and we see a picture of the thi UNICORN, exhibited in a glass case. The considerable thickness of the glass is apparent.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Blistering blue barnacles, that is the Unicorn!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain, do you see the distortion around the model - it means Ben Salaad exhibits it in a bullet proof glass case in hia palace!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: And sakharine is going there to steal it!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: He has a secret weapon, The Milanese Nightingale. But that won't be enough to solve the mystery, and that is why Sakharine needs you. That's why he made you his prisoner! There is something he needs you to remember.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I don’t follow you.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I read it in a book. That only a true Haddock can discover the secret of the Unicorn. They look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I don't remember anything about anything!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: But you must know about your ancestor, Sir Francie. It’s your family legacy!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: My memory isn’t what it uged to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sl.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What did it use to be?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I’ve forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain, can you get us to Bagghar?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: What sort of a atupid question is that? Give me those oars, I'11 show you some real seamanship, laddie. ANGLE ON: HADDOCK stands and moves to TINTIN, snatches up oars.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘ll not be doubted by some pipsqueak tuft of ginger and his irritating dog! I am master and commander of the seas! He swings them expertly over his shoulder, turning hie ba on TINTIN. CLOSE ON: WHACK! The OAR clunks TINTIN on the side of his HEAD, knocking him out cold. AS HADDOCK completes his tur hite SNOWY out cold too!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know these waters better than the warts on my mother’s face! HADDOCK glances back over his shoulder, where TINTIN and SNOWY are slumped unconscious against the side of the ROWBOAT.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at the pair of them - fast asleep! Typical landlubbere, no stamina these days! Nevermind. 1711 get ya there, Tintin. ANGLE ON: HADDOCK heaves back on the OARS ... EXT. SILK’S APARTMENT - DAY ANGLE ON: The familiar PATENT SHOES and GLOVED HANDS of t PICKPOCKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMSON and THOMPSON stroll down the street, SHOPS and APARTMENTS behind them. The PICKPOCKET, ARISTIDES SILK, s them coming.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Look, Thomson! There's the fellow.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Uh huh! He tries to look casual as he reaches for his KEYS.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Oh my!

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Mr. Silk?

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: My name is Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: And Thomson.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON/THOMSON
dialogues.text: We're police officers!

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, crumbs! SILK'S first thought is to make a run for it. He turns an does just that. A CRASH is heard. The THOM(P)SONS run ove him.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Goodness gracious!

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Mr. Silk! SILK has slammed into an OLD WOMAN carrying a cage of CANARIES from a PET SHOP. He is in a heap with three litt YELLOW CANARIES fluttering around his head.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Are you ok?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Poor fella...

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir? The little CANARIES are real. A PET SHOP OWNER retrievea with a net as a MAN helps the OLD WOMAN. THOMSON and THOMPSON together get SILK to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No need to run away, sir.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: No, no. You see. Yesterday, we very nearly caught the pickpocket who's been terrorizing the town.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (dazed) Pickpocket.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: We pulled his jacket off and inside we found a wallet. THOMPSON produces the WALLET.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: A wallet with your name and address.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (dazed) That's my wallet.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: It’s obviously stolen from you.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: No, no! That’s my wallet!

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: We didn’t mean to startle you. Let us help you into your apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: The DOOR to SILK’S APARTMENT burats open, the THOM(P)SONS are framed in the doorway ... a battered and baffled SILK stands between them, attempting to fend them off.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (nervous } Thank you so much. No need to come in. I'11 be quite alright really.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: No, we insist!

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Better safe than sorry. It’s the least we can do.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you,

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: There we are. SILK takes a seat in his ARMCHAIR. ANGLE ON: A bookshelf packed with HUNDREDS of WALLETS sit the middle of the room. All of WALLETS are nearly labeled filed. The THOM()PSON's Look at it, stunned. SILK looks at them nervously - figuring the game is up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good grief,what’s all this?

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: It's my... collection.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: What a lot of wallets.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: I can't help it... it started with coin purses and sort of went on from there, really...

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: You want to be careful. Haven’t you heard? There's a pickpocket about!  55.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: (looking around the room) Yes, he'd love this - can you imagine?

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (offended) What do you mean “pickpocket?”

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Oh, a master criminal: a bag- snatching, purse-pilfering, wallet- lifting, sneak thief. CLOSE ON: SILK's lower lip starts to quiver, his composur goes.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (confessing) I'm not a bad person ... I'ma kleptomaniac. THOMPSON looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: A what? THOMSON leans over and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: (whispers) It‘s a fear of open spaces.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (whispers) Poor man. No wonder he keeps his wallets in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (rapture) Wallets! I just can't resist the lovely little things. It‘'a a, it’s a harmleas little habit, really. THOMPSON takes a WALLET and checks the NAME TAG.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Good heavens! Thomson - look at this! His name’s Thompson too!

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Oh, what a coincidence! THOMSON takes another WALLET off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, Thompson, this is Thomson without a ‘P’ ~ as in psychic.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: No, no, no, it’s Thompson with a *P’ - as in psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Look at this one. A green one that I managed to pick from a pickpocket actually pickpocketing at the time. And this one...

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: How dare you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: How dare YOU, sir?

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Good heavens, Thomson - you've got it all wrong. THOMSON brandishes a WALLET at THOMPSON. BOTH THOM(P)SONS are taking WALLET after WALLET off the shelf, until they an armful each!

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: No, you have it all wrong and there is a ’P' in psychic.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: I’m not your sidekick. You are mine.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Oh, smell it, won't you? Piggy leather. Oh, I love piggy leather.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: How dare you?

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: How dare you? I met you first.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: I met you first.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: No, you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.  57.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: No, you did not.

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Didn't!

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Did!

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Didn't! SILK is talking to himself while the THOMPSON and THOMSON argue.

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: (breaking down) Listen! I can't stand it anymore! Alright, I'll come quietly! SILK begins thrusting WALLETS at the THOM(P)SONS.

dialogues.speaker: SILK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Take them, take them -

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SILK
dialogues.text: Take them all!

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Pull yourself together, man! We can’t take your wallets,do we look like thieves??

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON

dialogues.text: It ist

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh, 80 cold! And thirsty! My throat is parched! Let’s see if there's any fresh water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HADDOCK leans over to a hatch in the prow, opens it and finds... a BOTTLE of RUM!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (conflicted) Ohhh! What have we here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: A sleeping TINTIN slowly opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Tintin! Tintin! Come and warm yourself, laddy. ANOTHER ANGLE: On a BLAZING FIRE in the middle of the BOA HADDOCK casually warms himself.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain... ? What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: No need to thank me!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (shocked) What?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Well, you looked a little cold. So I lit a wee fire.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: In a boat? No, those are our oars! We need those oars!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Yes, but not for much longer!  59.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Have you gone mad? ANGLE ON: TINTIN leans over the side of the boat and begi to scoop water in his hands, trying to put out the flames TINTIN (CONT‘D) Quick, Captain! Help me! Captain, help me quick!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: He's right! What have I done? What have I done? HADDOCK picks up the BOTTLE which is still half full of alcohol. HADDOCK upturns the bottle on the flames which s up -

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: No, Captain - not that! ANGLE ON: The BOAT, off in the distance, erupts into FLAM

dialogues.text: Thundering typhoona! ANGLE ON: TINTIN and HADDOCK are sitting on the upturned boat. A small hole in the boat and glowing embers sit bet them.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Well, this is a fine mess.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I’m weak...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: We're stranded here...

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Selfish...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: With no hope of rescue.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Hopeless!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: While Sakharine and his men are halfway to Bagghar.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Poor, miserable wretch!  60. TINTIN finally turns to HADDOCK. He shakea

dialogues.text: Yes, all right! That‘s enough of that.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: It was his fault, you see. It was Sir Francis!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Tell me, how do you work that one out?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Because he was a figurehead of great courage and bold exploits! No one like him has ever existed in my family! Why do you think I drink? It’s because I know I'11 never be like him! No, it’s far better that I end it now and put us both out of our misery. TINTIN’s hand as SNOWY whines; he attracts TINTIN’S to a DISTANT SPECK in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What is it, Snowy? An approaching AIRPLANE ... TINTIN's concerned.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I'm going to lower myself into the sea... into the cold embrace into the big blue. The SEAPLANE has spotted the upturned boat... it starts t turn towards them.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Those are Portuguese markings. He turns to BADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Are you even listening?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Where is the Karaboudjan registered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: HADDOCK spots the AIRPLANE ... he leaps onto th hull of the upturned boat and starts waving and jumpingalarmingly!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: We're saved! We're saved!!! Oh, it’s a sign from above!!! SUDDENLY! MACHINE GUN FIRE spits from the SEAPLANE, as it zooms low over TINTIN and HADDOCK, STRAFING THEM! TINTIN HADDOCK nearly fall into the WATER as BULLETS shred the H HE STANDS UP AGAIN. ANGLE ON: The SEAPLANE turns for another ATTACK RUN ... dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Troglodytes!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain, get down!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (yelling) Slave traders! Mutant malingerers! Freshwater politicians!! ANGLE ON: The SEAPLANE starts its attack run. TINTIN produces his PISTOL, checks the CLIP.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Bad news, Captain - we've only got one bullet!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (aghast) What’s the good news?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: . We've got one bullet. ANGLE ON: TINTIN holds his ground as BULLETS ZING around him. . TINTIN aims, using BOTH HANDS to steady his PISTOL. BANG! He fires! The SEAPLANE roars low over their HEADS . HADDOCK falls into the OCEAN.  62. ANGLE ON: Black SMOKE spews out of the SEAPLANE'S ENGINE! SEAPLANE loses power and is forced to LAND.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: {joyous ) You got him!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Ah! Well done, my boy. TINTIN and SNOWY jump into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: The PLANE bobs uselessly on the water. TWO PILO jump out onto the FLOATS before it comes to a stop. They to the engine and open the hood. As a huge cloud of smoke comes out, the pilot quickly checks under the cowling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTIN and HADDOCK hide on the far side of the overturned ROWBOAT.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Stay here, Captain. TINTIN dives under the water.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Tintin! Tintin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PILOT continues to inspect the PLANE.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Don't take your eyes off of them!

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Just as I thought, the ignition lead has been cut! Ah! Lucky shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN’S COIF cuts through the water like a SHARK’S FIN.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: One more pass and we will finish them off. Suddenly, TINTIN surfaces at the end of the FLOAT... PIST aimed straight at the PILOTS!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Put your hands in the air! THE PILOTS stare at TINTIN, amazed. TINTIN (CONT’D) Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN reads through the FLIGHT INSTRUCTION MANUAL. HADDO sits behind him. The PILOTS are tied up in the back of th plane.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (worried) You, you do know what your doing, eh, Tintin?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Um, more or less. TINTIN flicks a switch. The plane GRUMBLES into life.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Well, which is it? More or less? The PLANE taxis along the WATER.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Relax! I interviewed a pilot once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SEAPLANE rises into the SKY.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Which way to North Africa? The SEAPLANE SOARS through the sky, several hundred feet above the WAVES.  44. ANGLE ON: A DARK SPECK below them... TINTIN swoops down f CLOSER LOOK: the KARABOUDJAN! It’s ploughing towards BAGG at high speed.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Captain! Look! We've caught up with them!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Wonderful! But do you think, we might find another way to North Africa that doesn't take us through that Wall of Death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: The SEAPLANE is flying DIRECTLY towards a TOWER WALL of brewing BLACK CLOUD, RAIN SQUALL and HIGH WIND.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: We can’t turn back - not now! (to himself) Not now. The SEAPLANE starts to buck and shake in the GATHERING ST ANGLE ON: The TINY PLANE is tossed around as the STORM ra around it. Lightening forks FLASH frighteningly close. Th SEAPLANE PITCBES and ROLLS alarmingly. HADDOCK spots MEDICINAL SPIRITS and quietly reaches for t BOTTLE. TINTIN spots him and swats his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, Captain! Those a surgical spirits for medicinal purposes only.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Quiet right, laddy, quiet right. The STORM outside worsens, and the PLANE does a BARREL RO Once TINTIN rights the PLANE, HADDOCK makes another grab the SPIRITS. He unscrews the CAP as the PLANE goes into a DIVE. The PILOTS float off the floor of the COCKPIT and t ALCOHOL emerges in the form of large GLOBULES that hover front of HADDOCK’s face. SNOWY floats into view and SLURPS up the ALCOHOL! TINTIN pulls the PLANE out of the dive at the last moment and SN crashes to the FLOOR and BURPS.  65. The PLANE goes into another dive and more alcohol emerges from the BOTTLE. HADDOCK grabs SNOWY'’S TONGUE and sucks down as quick as he can. TINTIN steadies the PLANE again and the PILOTS are knocke out by the return of gravity. The propellor comes to a st

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: No, no, no! A RED LIGHT FLASHES next to the FUEL GAUGE.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuel tank! It’s almost empty. Captain! This may sound crazy but I've got a plan. The alcohol in that bottle may give us a few more miles. I need you to climb out of the plane and pour it into the fuel tank,

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Christopher Columbus! HADDOCK buckles the belt on his PARACHUTE. HADDOCK opens the door for a moment. He quickly pulls it shut. HADDOCK (CONT‘D) (defiantly) There's a terrible storm out there! And it’s raining!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: And you call yourself a Haddock? HADDOCK glowers, getting his nerve before again opening t door. He immediately falls out of view. TINTIN (CONT’D) Captain! Captain! Can you hear me? Captain! Captain! HADDOCK'S head slowly appears in TINTIN‘'s window.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re doing fine! Now, pour the bottle into the tank. We’re running on fumes! HADDOCK has an idea.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Fumes! HADDOCK straddles the plane and opens the FUEL CAP. Insid the cockpit, the empty ALCOHOL BOTTLE hits TINTIN’S foot.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no. HADDOCK takes a big breath and releases an ENORMOUS BELCH into the TANK. Inside the ENGINE, PISTONS fire manically FLAMES shoot out from the propellor as it spine again. HADDOCK sits up and block the WINDSHIELD.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Captain! I can’t see! HADDOCK sees something and POINTS.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Land, land!!!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: We can’t! We’re not there yet!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: No, LAND!!! Suddenly, a SAND DUNE appears and the PLANE is headed straight for it!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turn!! TINTIN does his best to avoid a the DUNE. The plane pitch wildly back and forth. The PILOTS have regained consciousness in the back and sh their heads. HADDOCK (CONT’D) Starboard! Starboard! Starboard!! TINTIN swerves the PLANE again. The PILOTS have freed themselves from their BINDINGS. Still on the nose of the PLANE, HADDOCK is struck by LIGHTNING, YELLS and flips over the PLANE as his PARACHUT deploye! He grabs the RUDDER before being pulled into the air, SCREAMING, The PILOTS exit the plane door, deploying their own chutes and drifting into the desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLANE hits a dune, catches fire and comes to a stop. TINTIN is thrown through the WINDSHIELD and slides down t nose of the plane, towards the spinning PROPELLER.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hang on, Tintin! I‘m coming!! SNOWY tries to pull him to safety, but his QUIFF is trimm by the ROTORS. HADDOCK reaches the PLANE and pulls TINTIN to SAFETY, bef his CHUTE is pulled into the PROPELLER and he is thrown i the SAND. SNOWY faints as TINTIN gradually regains consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE ON: SUN BLAZES DOWN mercilessly, as TINTIN, HADDOCK SNOWY trudge through the SEA OF SAND, KNOTTED HANDKERCHIE on their HEADS. TINTIN is deep in thought. HADDOCK ia dee gloom.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The Land of Thirst... the Land of Thirst! The Land of Thirst!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Will you stop saying that!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (gasping) You don’t understand. I’ve run out, I’ve run out. ANGLE ON: HADDOCK gets on his knees. HADDOCK (CONT’D) You don’t know what that means. HADDOCK is in bad shape... TINTIN supports him.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain, we have to keep going. One step at a time. Come on, on your feet. Lean your weight on me.

dialogues.text: A man can only hang on for so long without his vitals.

dialogues.text: (excited) Look, Tintin! We're saved! Water! Water! HADDOCK breaka into a run... SNOWY tries to stop him by BITING his dangling SUSPENDERS. They snap back int

dialogues.text: Stop, Captain! It’s just a mirage! HADDOCK stumbles forward, ending up DAZED and looking around the ROLLING SAND DUNES.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (confused) But it was here... I saw it...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: It was juat your mind playing tricks... it's the heat. HADDOCK, as his EYES fill with EMOTION.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: I have to go home,

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What... ?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: TI have to go back to the sea.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain, you're hallucinating! HADDOCK points towards a dune.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Look, did you ever see a more beautiful sight? TINTIN looks towards the dune: nothing but rolling hills blistering Ssand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HADDOCK {CONT’D) (awestruck) She’s turning into the wind, all sails set! HADDOCK starts to get up. HADDOCK (CONT‘D) Triple-masted, double decks, fifty guns... CLOSE ON: TINTIN stops in his tracks...

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (softly) The Unicorn?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Isn‘t she a beauty?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (encouraging) Yes, yes she is! Tell me, Captain - what else can you see?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: She's got the wind behind her! Look at the pace she’s setting! Barely a day out of Barbados, a hold full of rum and the finest tobacco and the hearts of the sailors set for home! ANGLE ON : HADDOCK’S Pov... three masts in full sail, fly the KING'S ENSIGN, slides into view in the DESERT - the S at first hidden by a HIGH SAND DUNE. dialogues.text: The red pennant TRANSITION: SIR FRANCIS'S proud face dissolves into that hia deacendant, a more fearful captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HADDOCK turna to face TINTIN.

dialogues.text: The blood runs cold of every sea captain who looks upon that flag, for he knows he's facing a fight to the death. But Sir Francis is a Haddock, and Haddock'a don't flee. dialogues.text: Aye, aye Captain! Prepare to bring her about! ANGLE ON: The UNICORN SMASHES into a VAST WAVE, which BRE across her bow. The PIRATE SHIP crests a wave just behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: And then he saw him, like a phantom, rising from the dead.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (captivated) Who? CLOSE ON: HADDOCK, parched. Thick grime cakes his lips, s runs down his face... he struggles to maintain focus. TINTIN (CONT’D) Captain? Captain, who did he see? dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (bewildered) It’s gone...  72.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: What do you mean gone? What happened next?! BADDOCK is becoming CONFUSED, struggling to remember.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: By Jupiter, I have a beard! Since when did I have a beard?!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain, something happened on the Unicorn! It’s the key to everything! You must try to remember !

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The Unicorn? What? I'm so terribly thirsty. HADDOCK sways on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Captain!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (fearful) Tintin... What is happening to me? CLOSE ON: TINTIN catches HADPOCK as he falls forward, the lowers him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: And to think all it took was a day in the Sahara. Congratulations, Captain. You're sober.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Sober... HADDOCK passes out. WIDE ON: The solitary figure of TINTIN holding the inert of HADDOCK in hie arms... againat the vast backdrop of th SAHARA as the huge ORANGE SUN sinks below the HORIZON.

dialogues.speaker: DELCOURT
dialogues.text: Good dog! This one’s alive! Check the other!

dialogues.speaker: AFGHAR OUTPOST SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Yes sir! The other SOLDIER inspects HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COLONIAL FOREIGN LEGION FORT. TINTIN and SNOWY are led prim, proper, pipe-smoking BRITISH OFFICER, DELCOURT.

dialogues.speaker: DELCOURT
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Delcourt, welcome to the Afghar Outpost.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lieutenant. We owe you our lives. Did you find my friend?

dialogues.speaker: DELCOURT
dialogues.text: Yes,but he’s not in good shape, I'm afraid. He’s still suffering the effects of acute dehydration. He's quite delirious. Why don’t we pay him a visit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: DELCOURT opens a DOOR to reveal a makeshift infirmary. HADDOCK turns towards them as they enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: DELCOURT
dialogues.text: Ah, Haddock - you’re awake, good. I have a visitor for you. DELCOURT steps back to reveal TINTIN.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain...  74. HADDOCK turne to greet his GUEST ... NO SIGN of recogniti

dialogues.text: Hello! £ think you've got the wrong room.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Captain? It’s Tintin. Our plane crashed in the desert, don’t you remember?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Plane? No, no, I'm a naval man, myself. I never fly if I can help it. He’s got me confused with someone else. {looks at the glass he ia holding ) What is this peculiar Liquid? There’s no bouquet, it’s completely transparent.

dialogues.speaker: DELCOURT
dialogues.text: Why, it’s water.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: What will they think of next?

dialogues.speaker: DELCOURT
dialogues.text: Well, we suspect he has a concussion, heatstroke, delirium. SNOWY goes to the table next to the door, he grabs a BOTT of “MEDICINE”. CLOSE ON: The “MEDICINE” is a BOTTLE of WHISKEY! !!!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: He's sober. TINTIN takes the water glass and hands it to DELCOURT. TI is focused on HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now Captain, out in the desert.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The desert? SNOWY walks back and sets the bottle on the side table ne to HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, you were talking about Sir Francis. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Sir who?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Sir Francis, and you were telling me about what happened on the Unicorn.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The Unicorn?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: The stuff that dreams are made of, wee children’s dreams.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: No, the ship! Oh, please try to remember, Captain. Lives are at risk. HADDOCK reaches for the glass, SNOWY pushes the bottle in place, HADDOCK grabs the bottle and drinks the WHISKEY in gulp! TINTIN looks back in horror.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Snowy! What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhh! TINTIN turns to DELCOURT and the SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: I'd stand back if I were you. HADDOCK starts to get louder.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (urgent) Out! Everybody out of the room!!!! They all run out; TINTIN grabs SNOWY and closes the door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRANSITION: HADDOCK jumps at the DOOR, sending splinters all directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HADDOCK runs along a wall, LUNGING with his SWORD!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Show yourself, Red Rackham!

dialogues.text: RED RACKHAM steps out of the shadows and into the light. FRANCIS sees him, runs forward to engage but is intercept by two PIRATES. TRANSITION: The two PIRATES become TINTIN and DELCOURT, circling HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: HADDOCK leaps on a TABLE, facing off against th INVISIBLE FOE he sees in his MIND‘S EYE.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (roaring) If it’s a fight you want - you’ve met your match!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: A fight with who? TINTIN looks on, SNOWY safely with him.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (charging) To the death...

dialogues.speaker: RED RACKHAM
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: RED RACKHAM side-steps SIR FRANCIS, takes off h CAPE and throws it over SIR FRANCIS. He swings SIR FRANCI around, sending him crashing into crates and barrels. A falling piece of the mast turns into a WOODEN CEILING FAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: A HEAVY WOODEN CEILING FAN crashes down on HADDOCK'S HEAD, knocking him SENSELESS! TRANSITION: SOLDIERS run into the office. TINTIN stops th We swirl around to see the oncoming GUARDS become PIRATES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWORDS surround SIR FRANCIS, who lies on the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TINTIN crouches down beside HADDOCK.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: (concerned) Captain? ANGLE ON: HADDOCK sits up, ashen-faced... a desolate ligh his eyes. TINTIN takes his sword and hands it to DELCOURT

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (quiet, reverie) I remember everything now. Everything Granddaddy told me. The Unicorn was taken. The pirates were now the masters of the ship.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: The crew surrendered?

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: Granddaddy said that Red Rackham called Sir Francis the King’s dog - a pirate hunter sent to reclaim their hard won plunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR FRANCIS is lashed to the MAST by RED RACKHAM’S MEN.

dialogues.speaker: RED RACKHAM
dialogues.text: Why would I waste my time on rum, tobacco, molasses, and dates when you have a more valuable cargo on board? Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: SIR FRANCIS
dialogues.text: You'll have to kill me first.  78.

dialogues.speaker: RED RACKHAM
dialogues.text: (smiling evilly) Not first, no. I will start with your men. TRANSITION: RED RACKHAM raises his sword. We push past to FRANCIS on the MAST. TINTIN steps behind the MAST and we transition back to the OUTPOST with the CAPTAIN standing his CHAIR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HADDOCK is back on his feet; he moves around the room and TINTIN follows.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: To save his men, he would give up the secret cargo.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: And where was it? TRANSITION: HADDOCK walks to the BOOKSHELF and slowly rem one, as though he is pulling a LEVER.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: 400 weight of gold, jewels, and treasure. We are behind RACKHAM, who steps in the middle of it and lifts the mask off his face to get a better look, althoug do not see his face. Slowly lowering the mask, he turns, gesturing with his sword top side.

dialogues.speaker: RED RACKHAM
dialogues.text: Kill his men!

dialogues.text: No, Rackham, no!!!

dialogues.text: I don't understand. Who's after your blood!

dialogues.text: Sank his own ship! Sir Francie sent that treasure to the bottom of the sea. He would be damned before he let Red Rackham have it.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: And he was.

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: But he couldn't let it lie.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: He left a clue! Three clues wrapped in a riddle, concealing a secret. But only a true Haddock will be able to solve it.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: What secret?

dialogues.speaker: TINTIN
dialogues.text: The location to one of the greatest sunken treasures in all history.

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK
dialogues.text: (realizing) The wreck of the Unicorn. He means to steal it. The third scroll! Billions of blue-blistering barnacles, I swear, as the last of the Haddocks, I'll find that treasure before him!

dialogues.speaker: HADDOCK

dialogues.text: Yes, well, bit of a long story, that.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON

dialogues.text: (tense) It's not the money I'm worried about. CLOSE ON: TINTIN walks and turns away. He hurriedly fishe into his WALLET and produces the neatly folded SCROLL!
